content: 'One man with courage makes a majority.' - Andrew Jackson 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.' - Franklin D. Roosevelt 'The buck stops here.' - Harry S. Truman 'Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.' - John F. Kennedy And for today's Democrats... 'It depends what your definition of 'IS' is?'' - Bill Clinton 'That Obama - I would like to cut his NUTS off.' - Jesse Jackson 'Those rumors are false .... I believe in the sanctity of marriage.' - John Edwards 'I invented the Internet' - Al Gore 'The next Person that tells me I'm not religious, I'm going to shove my rosary beads up their ASS.' - Joe Biden ' America is--is no longer, uh, what it--it, uh, could be, uh what it was once was...uh, and I say to myself, 'uh, I don't want that future, uh, uh for my children.' - Barack Obama 'I have campaigned in all 57 states. - Barack Obama 'You don't need God anymore, you have us democrats.' - Nancy Pelosi (said back in 2006) 'Paying taxes is voluntary.' - Sen. Harry Reid 'Bill is the greatest husband and father I know. No one is more faithful, true, and honest than he.' - Hillary Clinton (said back in 1998) "Diplomacy is utterly useless when there is no force behind it; the diplomat is the servant, not the master of the soldier." THEODORE ROOSEVELT

content: Don't get too enamored with the four former presidents first mentioned. Remember what else they said: "Of course I'll help you after the war. After all, you've helped me." Andrew Jackson to his Cherokee and Choctaw allies sometime BEFORE he evicted them and sent them on the Trail of Tears. "He's nice. Reminds me of my uncle" Franklin Rooseveldt to Churchill about Josef Stalin "Nuke em. Twice." Harry S. Truman "Ich bien ein Berliner" John F. Kennedy Note: a 'Berliner' is a type of pastry. In effect, the literal translation is 'I am a cream puff.' The Russians took him at his word - two years later, the wire and mine Berlin Wall became a true reinforced concrete wall. It stood for another twenty four years. In contrast, two years after Reagan said to tear it down, it came down. Sullivan013

And of course there's the famous or is that infamous line from Tricky Dick. Frost: "So ... what ... you're saying is that there are certain situations ... where the president can decide that it's in the best interests of the nation or something, and do something illegal." Nixon: "Well, when the president does it that means that it is not illegal." Frost: " By definition." Nixon: "Exactly, exactly. If the president, for example, approves something because of the national security ... then the president's decision in that instance is one that enables those who carry it out to carry it out without violating a law."

content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: Speaking of the perv voting block, ACLU? NAMBLA? Ring any bells? Does the KKK, Timothy McVeigh or Eric Rudolph ring any for you? President Truman and Senator Byrd, both Democrats, were members of the klan. In 1924, Harry S. Truman was a judge in Jackson County, Missouri, which includes Kansas City. Truman was up for reelection, and his friends Edgar Hinde and Spencer Salisbury advised him to join the Klan. The Klan was politically powerful in Jackson County, and two of Truman's opponents in the Democratic primary had Klan support. Truman refused at first, but paid the Klan's $10 membership fee, and a meeting with a Klan officer was arranged. West Virginia's Democratic Senator Robert Byrd was a recruiter for the Klan while in his 20s and 30s, rising to the title of Kleagle and Exalted Cyclops of his local chapter. After leaving the group, Byrd spoke in favor of the Klan during his early political career. Though he claimed to have left the organization in 1943, Byrd wrote a letter in 1946 to the group's Imperial Wizard stating “The Klan is needed today as never before, and I am anxious to see its rebirth here in West Virginia.” Byrd defended the Klan in his 1958 U.S. Senate campaign when he was 41 years old. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notable_alleged_Ku_Klux_Klan_members_in_national_politics" For decades the democratic party was the party of segregation and Jim Crow.
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: Speaking of the perv voting block, ACLU? NAMBLA? Ring any bells? Does the KKK, Timothy McVeigh or Eric Rudolph ring any for you?

West Virginia's Democratic Senator Robert Byrd was a recruiter for the Klan while in his 20s and 30s, rising to the title of Kleagle and Exalted Cyclops of his local chapter. After leaving the group, Byrd spoke in favor of the Klan during his early political career. Though he claimed to have left the organization in 1943, Byrd wrote a letter in 1946 to the group's Imperial Wizard stating “The Klan is needed today as never before, and I am anxious to see its rebirth here in West Virginia.” Byrd defended the Klan in his 1958 U.S. Senate campaign when he was 41 years old. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notable_alleged_Ku_Klux_Klan_members_in_national_politics" For decades the democratic party was the party of segregation and Jim Crow. yea funny how so many dems want to change that part of their past so much that they just dont teach kids that anymore... its a shame more of that trying to change our past instead of learning it so they dont repeat it... quote: The first Klan was founded in 1865 by veterans of the Confederate Army. Its purpose was to restore white supremacy in the aftermath of the American Civil War. The Klan resisted Reconstruction by intimidating freedmen and white Republicans, members of the abolitionist movement. The KKK quickly adopted violent methods. The increase in murders finally resulted in a backlash among Southern elites who viewed the Klan's excesses as an excuse for federal troops to continue occupation. Lifting the Klan mask revealed a chaotic multitude of antiblack vigilante groups, disgruntled poor white farmers, wartime guerrilla bands, displaced Democratic politicians, illegal whiskey distillers, coercive moral reformers, sadists, rapists, white workmen fearful of black competition, employers trying to enforce labor discipline, common thieves, neighbors with decades-old grudges, and even a few freedmen and white Republicans who allied with Democratic whites or had criminal agendas of their own. Indeed, all they had in common, besides being overwhelmingly white, southern, and Democratic, was that they called themselves, or were called, Klansmen.[16] Cartoon from 1868, which accuses the Democratic party presidential candidates of relying on support from Ku Klux Klan members who were Confederate traitors in 1864

content: quote: Timothy McVeigh, Eric Rudolph AND the craziest of the racists all belong to the GOP now. Curious, but by what standard would they be Republicans? Lower taxes? Smaller government? Somehow I doubt that even registered on their radar screens. Evangelical Christianity? Now here we're getting close, but still not hitting the mark. Racism? Not really a factor with those guys, so we default back to your exalted Grand Kleagle from West Virginia. Neither Rudolph nor McVeigh gave a rat's ass about whether or not the people they killed and maimed were black or white. They just simply didn't care. They made their statements, and the only relevant color was the red blood that they splattered. Their causes were not the causes of the Republican Party, and any overlap on the abortion issue was prima facie incidental. Timothy McVeigh was motivated by The Turner Diaries, a book written by a National Socialist. Do I really need to rehash the intellectual wellspring and roots of that movement? Do I really need to ask which party is closer to the principles which launched that movement? Here's a clue, and I won't charge you for it. Your party is over. The whole "racist white Republican" thing is over. Why? Because white alleged Republicans elected your candidate to represent the country in its highest office. So you may now stop sounding like some idiotic discredited talking point that went stale sometime around 1989. I know. That kinda sucks for you, because that means you need to relearn how to think independently. And I can be sympathetic, up to a point, but it's now your responsibility to adjust to the new paradigm. "Hope and Change" have consigned the vast previous swath of human history to the ash heap. Up is Down and Down is Up; we have always been at war with Oceana. You know what, forget the sympathy. I do not care what your background is, all I know is that you're a cheerleader for the nightmare your Messiah has planned for us. I've seen that nightmare before and do not need a rerun. You're quite happy with a boot permanently placed upon a human face as long as your foot is in the boot and the face belongs to someone else. Principle doesn't even factor into the equation. I'm not going to call you a fascist or a communist, because that would mean you are an active supporter of those systems. I do not believe that you are. But I do see you as the sort who would allow either one of those systems to prevail if it gave lip service to your pet causes--principles be damned. And that, my dear, is far worse than calling you a fascist....
quote: Timothy McVeigh, Eric Rudolph AND the craziest of the racists all belong to the GOP now.
reply: Curious, but by what standard would they be Republicans? Lower taxes? Smaller government? Somehow I doubt that even registered on their radar screens. Evangelical Christianity? Now here we're getting close, but still not hitting the mark. Racism? Not really a factor with those guys, so we default back to your exalted Grand Kleagle from West Virginia. Neither Rudolph nor McVeigh gave a rat's ass about whether or not the people they killed and maimed were black or white. They just simply didn't care. They made their statements, and the only relevant color was the red blood that they splattered. Their causes were not the causes of the Republican Party, and any overlap on the abortion issue was prima facie incidental. Timothy McVeigh was motivated by The Turner Diaries, a book written by a National Socialist. Do I really need to rehash the intellectual wellspring and roots of that movement? Do I really need to ask which party is closer to the principles which launched that movement? Here's a clue, and I won't charge you for it. Your party is over. The whole "racist white Republican" thing is over. Why? Because white alleged Republicans elected your candidate to represent the country in its highest office. So you may now stop sounding like some idiotic discredited talking point that went stale sometime around 1989. I know. That kinda sucks for you, because that means you need to relearn how to think independently. And I can be sympathetic, up to a point, but it's now your responsibility to adjust to the new paradigm. "Hope and Change" have consigned the vast previous swath of human history to the ash heap. Up is Down and Down is Up; we have always been at war with Oceana. You know what, forget the sympathy. I do not care what your background is, all I know is that you're a cheerleader for the nightmare your Messiah has planned for us. I've seen that nightmare before and do not need a rerun. You're quite happy with a boot permanently placed upon a human face as long as your foot is in the boot and the face belongs to someone else. Principle doesn't even factor into the equation. I'm not going to call you a fascist or a communist, because that would mean you are an active supporter of those systems. I do not believe that you are. But I do see you as the sort who would allow either one of those systems to prevail if it gave lip service to your pet causes--principles be damned. And that, my dear, is far worse than calling you a fascist....
title: Great Orators of the Democrat Party

content: 'One man with courage makes a majority.' - Andrew Jackson 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.' - Franklin D. Roosevelt 'The buck stops here.' - Harry S. Truman 'Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.' - John F. Kennedy And for today's Democrats... 'It depends what your definition of 'IS' is?'' - Bill Clinton 'That Obama - I would like to cut his NUTS off.' - Jesse Jackson 'Those rumors are false .... I believe in the sanctity of marriage.' - John Edwards 'I invented the Internet' - Al Gore 'The next Person that tells me I'm not religious, I'm going to shove my rosary beads up their ASS.' - Joe Biden ' America is--is no longer, uh, what it--it, uh, could be, uh what it was once was...uh, and I say to myself, 'uh, I don't want that future, uh, uh for my children.' - Barack Obama 'I have campaigned in all 57 states. - Barack Obama 'You don't need God anymore, you have us democrats.' - Nancy Pelosi (said back in 2006) 'Paying taxes is voluntary.' - Sen. Harry Reid 'Bill is the greatest husband and father I know. No one is more faithful, true, and honest than he.' - Hillary Clinton (said back in 1998) "Diplomacy is utterly useless when there is no force behind it; the diplomat is the servant, not the master of the soldier." THEODORE ROOSEVELT

content: Don't get too enamored with the four former presidents first mentioned. Remember what else they said: "Of course I'll help you after the war. After all, you've helped me." Andrew Jackson to his Cherokee and Choctaw allies sometime BEFORE he evicted them and sent them on the Trail of Tears. "He's nice. Reminds me of my uncle" Franklin Rooseveldt to Churchill about Josef Stalin "Nuke em. Twice." Harry S. Truman "Ich bien ein Berliner" John F. Kennedy Note: a 'Berliner' is a type of pastry. In effect, the literal translation is 'I am a cream puff.' The Russians took him at his word - two years later, the wire and mine Berlin Wall became a true reinforced concrete wall. It stood for another twenty four years. In contrast, two years after Reagan said to tear it down, it came down. Sullivan013

And of course there's the famous or is that infamous line from Tricky Dick. Frost: "So ... what ... you're saying is that there are certain situations ... where the president can decide that it's in the best interests of the nation or something, and do something illegal." Nixon: "Well, when the president does it that means that it is not illegal." Frost: " By definition." Nixon: "Exactly, exactly. If the president, for example, approves something because of the national security ... then the president's decision in that instance is one that enables those who carry it out to carry it out without violating a law."

content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: Speaking of the perv voting block, ACLU? NAMBLA? Ring any bells? Does the KKK, Timothy McVeigh or Eric Rudolph ring any for you? President Truman and Senator Byrd, both Democrats, were members of the klan. In 1924, Harry S. Truman was a judge in Jackson County, Missouri, which includes Kansas City. Truman was up for reelection, and his friends Edgar Hinde and Spencer Salisbury advised him to join the Klan. The Klan was politically powerful in Jackson County, and two of Truman's opponents in the Democratic primary had Klan support. Truman refused at first, but paid the Klan's $10 membership fee, and a meeting with a Klan officer was arranged. West Virginia's Democratic Senator Robert Byrd was a recruiter for the Klan while in his 20s and 30s, rising to the title of Kleagle and Exalted Cyclops of his local chapter. After leaving the group, Byrd spoke in favor of the Klan during his early political career. Though he claimed to have left the organization in 1943, Byrd wrote a letter in 1946 to the group's Imperial Wizard stating “The Klan is needed today as never before, and I am anxious to see its rebirth here in West Virginia.” Byrd defended the Klan in his 1958 U.S. Senate campaign when he was 41 years old. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notable_alleged_Ku_Klux_Klan_members_in_national_politics" For decades the democratic party was the party of segregation and Jim Crow.
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: Speaking of the perv voting block, ACLU? NAMBLA? Ring any bells? Does the KKK, Timothy McVeigh or Eric Rudolph ring any for you?

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notable_alleged_Ku_Klux_Klan_members_in_national_politics" For decades the democratic party was the party of segregation and Jim Crow. yea funny how so many dems want to change that part of their past so much that they just dont teach kids that anymore... its a shame more of that trying to change our past instead of learning it so they dont repeat it... quote: The first Klan was founded in 1865 by veterans of the Confederate Army. Its purpose was to restore white supremacy in the aftermath of the American Civil War. The Klan resisted Reconstruction by intimidating freedmen and white Republicans, members of the abolitionist movement. The KKK quickly adopted violent methods. The increase in murders finally resulted in a backlash among Southern elites who viewed the Klan's excesses as an excuse for federal troops to continue occupation. Lifting the Klan mask revealed a chaotic multitude of antiblack vigilante groups, disgruntled poor white farmers, wartime guerrilla bands, displaced Democratic politicians, illegal whiskey distillers, coercive moral reformers, sadists, rapists, white workmen fearful of black competition, employers trying to enforce labor discipline, common thieves, neighbors with decades-old grudges, and even a few freedmen and white Republicans who allied with Democratic whites or had criminal agendas of their own. Indeed, all they had in common, besides being overwhelmingly white, southern, and Democratic, was that they called themselves, or were called, Klansmen.[16] Cartoon from 1868, which accuses the Democratic party presidential candidates of relying on support from Ku Klux Klan members who were Confederate traitors in 1864

content: This is like being in the school yard as an eight year old kid again!!! I KNOW YOU ARE BUT WHAT AM I ............. Utterly fargin' rediculous!!!!! What you need to see to figure it out is that NONE of these P's O.S. give a happy crap about YOU!! Then you can begin to understand politics!!!

title: Great Orators of the Democrat Party

content: quote: Timothy McVeigh, Eric Rudolph AND the craziest of the racists all belong to the GOP now. Curious, but by what standard would they be Republicans? Lower taxes? Smaller government? Somehow I doubt that even registered on their radar screens. Evangelical Christianity? Now here we're getting close, but still not hitting the mark. Racism? Not really a factor with those guys, so we default back to your exalted Grand Kleagle from West Virginia. Neither Rudolph nor McVeigh gave a rat's ass about whether or not the people they killed and maimed were black or white. They just simply didn't care. They made their statements, and the only relevant color was the red blood that they splattered. Their causes were not the causes of the Republican Party, and any overlap on the abortion issue was prima facie incidental. Timothy McVeigh was motivated by The Turner Diaries, a book written by a National Socialist. Do I really need to rehash the intellectual wellspring and roots of that movement? Do I really need to ask which party is closer to the principles which launched that movement? Here's a clue, and I won't charge you for it. Your party is over. The whole "racist white Republican" thing is over. Why? Because white alleged Republicans elected your candidate to represent the country in its highest office. So you may now stop sounding like some idiotic discredited talking point that went stale sometime around 1989. I know. That kinda sucks for you, because that means you need to relearn how to think independently. And I can be sympathetic, up to a point, but it's now your responsibility to adjust to the new paradigm. "Hope and Change" have consigned the vast previous swath of human history to the ash heap. Up is Down and Down is Up; we have always been at war with Oceana. You know what, forget the sympathy. I do not care what your background is, all I know is that you're a cheerleader for the nightmare your Messiah has planned for us. I've seen that nightmare before and do not need a rerun. You're quite happy with a boot permanently placed upon a human face as long as your foot is in the boot and the face belongs to someone else. Principle doesn't even factor into the equation. I'm not going to call you a fascist or a communist, because that would mean you are an active supporter of those systems. I do not believe that you are. But I do see you as the sort who would allow either one of those systems to prevail if it gave lip service to your pet causes--principles be damned. And that, my dear, is far worse than calling you a fascist....
quote: Timothy McVeigh, Eric Rudolph AND the craziest of the racists all belong to the GOP now.
